msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Numbers 22
ab.l:
And Balak, son of Zippor, saw
all that Israel had done to the Amorites.

And Moab was greatly afraid of the people
because they were many. And Moab weakened before of the children of Israel.

And Moab said to the elders of Midian,
‘Now this assembly will lick up all that are all around us, like the cattle licks
up the grass of the field.’ And Balak, son of Zippor,
was the king of the Moabites at that time.

And
he sent envoys to Balaam, son of Beor, to the city called Pethor
which is by the river of the land of the men
of his people, to call him, saying, ‘Lo, a people has come out
from Egypt. Lo, they cover the face of the earth, and they live
opposite me.

And now, come, curse
this people for me, because it is too powerful for me,
because I know that if you curse them, I will certainly be able to smite
them, and I will drive them out of the land — because I know:
the one whom you bless is blessed, and the one whom
you curse is cursed.’

And the elders of Moab
and the elders of Midian went with witchcraft in their hand,
and they came to Balaam and spoke to him the words of Balak.

And he said to them, ‘Lodge here this night,
and I will give you back a word of answer, as the
Lord shall speak to me.’ And the rulers of Moab abode with Balaam.

And an angel came to Balaam and said,
‘What are these men with you?’

And
Balaam said to the angel, ‘Balak, son of Zippor, king
of Moab, has sent to me,

Saying, “Lo,
here is a people who came out from Egypt, who cover the face of the
earth. Come now, curse them for me, because if you curse them,
I will certainly be able to fight with them and I will drive them away from me.”’

And the angel said to Balaam, ‘You shall not go with them.
You shall not curse the people, because they are blessed.’

And Balaam rose up at dawn and said to the rulers
of Balak, ‘Go to your land, because the Lord does not want to empower me
to go with you.’

And the rulers of Moab rose,
and they went to Balak and said,
‘Balaam does not want to come with us.’

And Balak went on again
to send greater and more honourable rulers
than these.

And they came to Balaam, and said to him,
‘Thus says Balak, son of Zippor, “I pray you, do not delay
with coming to me,

Because I will honour you very much,
and I will do all that you would say to me. Come now, curse
this people for me.”’

And
Balaam answered and said to the servants of Balak, ‘Though
Balak were to give me his house full of silver and gold, I would not be able
to go beyond the command of the Lord, my God, to do a small
thing or a big thing.

And now,
stay here, you as well, this night, so I may know what
the Lord will add to speak with me.’

And
an angel came to Balaam at night and said to him, ‘If
the men come to call you, rise up and go
with them. And just the word which I shall speak
to you — you shall do that.’

And Balaam rose up at dawn
and saddled his donkey and went with the rulers of Moab.

And God’s anger was kindled because he went. And
the angel of the Lord stood in the way as an adversary against him. And he was riding
on his donkey, and his two servants were with him.

And the donkey saw the angel of the Lord
standing in the way and his sword drawn in his hand.
And the donkey turned aside out of the way and went through the field.
And Balaam struck the donkey, to turn it to the way.

But the angel of the Lord stood in a path of the vineyards,
a fence being on this side and a wall on this side.

And the donkey saw the angel of the Lord and
it pressed itself against the wall and pressed Balaam’s foot
against the wall, and he continued hitting it.

And
the angel of the Lord continued passing on and stood in a narrow place where
there was no way to turn to the right or to the left.

And the donkey saw the angel of the Lord and it lay
down under Balaam. And Balaam’s anger was kindled, and he struck
the donkey with a staff.

And the Lord opened
the mouth of the donkey, and it said to Balaam, ‘What have I done
to you that you have struck me these three times?’

And
Balaam said to the donkey, ‘Because you have done recklessness to me. If
there were a sword in my hand I would have killed you by now!’

And the donkey said to Balaam, ‘Lo, I
am your donkey on which you have ever since your youth
to this day. Was I ever accustomed to do so to you?’ And
he said, ‘No.’

And the Lord opened the eyes
of Balaam, and he saw the angel of the Lord standing
in the way, and his sword drawn in his hand. And he bowed down and
worshiped on his face.

And the
angel of the Lord said to him, ‘Why have you struck your donkey these
three times? Lo, I went out to be an adversary against you, because
your way is distorted before me.

And
the donkey saw me and turned from me these three times.
If it had not turned from before me, I would have killed you, too, by now
and left it alive.’

And Balaam said
to the angel of the Lord, ‘I have sinned, because I did not know that you
stand in the way against me. And now, if it seems bad in your eyes,
let me go back to my place.’

And
the angel of the Lord said to Balaam, ‘Go with the men. And only
the word that I shall speak to you, that you shall speak.’ And
Balaam went with the rulers of Balak.

And
Balak heard that Balaam was coming, and he went out to meet him
to a city of Moab that is on the border of Arnon, which is on the edge
of the border.

And Balak said to Balaam, ‘Lo,
I sent to you to call you. Why did you not come to me?
Am I indeed not able to honour you?’

And Balaam
said to Balak, ‘Lo, even though I have come to you. Now:
will I be able to say any word? The word that God puts
in my mouth: that I will speak.’

And Balaam went with Balak,
and they came to Kiriath-Huzoth.

And
Balak sacrificed oxen and sheep, and sent for Balaam and for the rulers
that were with him.

And it was at dawn,
and Balak took Balaam and brought him up to Bamoth-Baal,
and he saw the |outer| edge of the people from there.

app.note: K: Num 22:1 is copied as Num 22:37; a scribal error.
